Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
It is difficult to assess the stability of a granular material, or to determine whether failure is imminent. The ability to non-invasively characterize changes in the mechanical state of a granular material would aid our understanding of the transition to failure. In both ordinary atomic/molecular systems and idealized jammed systems, the density of states provides a wealth of information about the state of the system. Acoustic measurements are a promising route to a similar characterization for granular materials, due to their ability to transmit vibrational energy into the bulk of the material, and to gather information in return. We will develop such techniques both in static and sheared systems where internal stresses are visible, as well as in more realistic three-dimensional materials which are of natural and industrial importance. Objectives are: (1) Simulations and analytics predict that an increased abundance of low-frequency modes is associated with an impending loss of rigidity. Do real granular materials exhibit this feature as a universal hallmark of incipient failure, e.g. under shear? (2) Simulated jammed materials with different shapes (circles vs. ellipses vs. dimers) each have a characteristic density of states. Do real granular materials, for instance those with corners, exhibit similar shape-dependent features? (3) The properties of force and contact networks may depend on the dimensionality of the system. Results from shear experiments may improve our understanding of earthquake nucleation and rupture. Connections to geophysics are possible by analyzing results in light of current ideas about foreshocks, tremors, triggering, and monitoring fault damage.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
Many energy-related industries rely on granular materials: extraction from oil sands, the handling of pellets within manufacturing facilities, the stability of rocks surrounding oil, gas, or carbon dioxide sequestration reservoirs, or flows within fluidized-bed reactors. It is difficult to assess the stability of a granular system: is failure imminent? what is the most stable direction to load the pile to avoid failure? The ability to non-invasively characterize changes in the mechanical state of a granular material would provide a means to evaluate such questions. Physicists have built a quantitative understanding of the mechanical stability of a broad class of materials such as foams, emulsions, and granular materials. Despite a decade of measurements within computer simulations, experimental progress has been slowed by the difficulty of making measurements in the interior of an opaque granular material. Acoustic techniques are a promising route due to their ability to penetrate the interior of opaque materials. We will develop new acoustical measurements which will open avenues for non-destructive testing of granular materials, research which will be conducted by undergraduate and graduate students. These new techniques will allow us to seek acoustical signatures of how close a system is to slipping, the direction of largest applied forces, or the degree of particle alignment/disorder. Beyond applications in the energy industry, the new techniques may be able to improve our understanding of how the granular material between tectonic plates becomes unstable and triggers earthquakes. The research team will also develop a related set of hands-on activities for use with local Girl Scouts troops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many energy-related industries rely on granular materials: for example extraction from oil sands, the handling of pellets within manufacturing facilities, the stability of rocks surrounding oil, gas, or carbon dioxide sequestration reservoirs, or flows within fluidized-bed reactors. It notoriously difficult to assess the stability of a granular system: is failure imminent? what is the most stable direction to load the pile to avoid failure?

 

In this project, we addressed these problems through laboratory experiments in which we controlled both the shape of the granular particles, and their loading history. Experiments were performed by students and postdoctoral researchers on several custom-built experiments designed to allow for full control of the loading conditions, as well as visual access to the internal forces/locations of the particles.

 

Using acoustic sensors embedded in the particles and/or the walls of experiments, we made two findings. First, that measurement of the acoustic density of modes (DOM) (a method of counting the different available vibrational frequencies) is able to distinguish among samples prepared under different amounts of disorder and compression. Second, that these acoustic DOM measurements can even be adapted to forecast the likelihood of a sample being slowly driven to mechanical failure. This opens avenues for non-destructive testing of granular materials in engineering contexts, for predicting how close a granular or agglomerated material is failure.

 

We examined how the loading at a boundary of a system creates a particular state within a granular material, using multiple experiments. For particles with different shapes, we found that while the acoustic DOM measurement changes depending on the particle shape, other properties do not. For instance, the rise in pressure as a material is compacted is largely independent of the particle shape, measured from the point of initial loading. In addition, we find that the statistics of failure (relative size and speed of failure events) depends dramatically on the roughness of the systems walls, and how compliant they are. Finally, we found the at the patterns of force transmission, visible in the images, is quite senstiive to the history of how the system was loaded.

 

These new findings and techniques will allow scientists and engineers to measure and forecast how close a system is to failure. Importantly, we hope that the techniques are also applicable to seismically active faults.

 

We engaged with the local community by developing and presenting a set of hands-on activities to local Girl Scout troops. We furthered the education of physics students at North Carolina State University by developing new laboratory activities based on professional-grade equipment, and by working with undergraduate researchers in the lab, including a pre-service teacher. We have disseminated our acoustical and optical techniques to the geology and physics communities through hands-on workshops for junior scientists, and through a submitted review article.
